Case 1:
Doctor: Hi! How are you feeling today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I’m feeling a bit better, but I still have some concerns.
Doctor: I see. Could you please share a little about yourself, and if you have any medical conditions or allergies?
Patient: Well ,  ‘ A 36 - year - old male doctor with no underlying medical illness or allergies was administered the first dose of the COVID-19 vaccine in a third hospital in Malaysia . ’
Doctor: Alright, thanks for sharing that. When did you first notice the symptoms related to your eyes?
Patient: I claimed to have two vision with generalized body aches about 3 h postvaccination .  Actually , it started ...
Doctor: I understand. Can you tell me more about how these eye symptoms progressed over time?
Patient: Sure ,  My myalgia and backache resolved after 1 day , and my right eye metamorphosia resolved after 3 days .  and then it continued ...
Doctor: Did you experience any other symptoms accompanying your eye problems?
Patient: Yes ,  No viral - like illness or symptoms , such as cough , upper respiratory tract illness , or fever , were reported before or after my shot .  were quite noticeable .
Doctor: I see. How has your left eye metamorphopsia been since the initial onset?
Patient: Well ,  Although it was still present , the symptoms had reduced in intensity , and the visual acuity had improved to 6/6 OU .  and it fluctuates sometimes .
Doctor: I see. Did you make any decisions regarding your vaccination after relating the symptoms to it?
Patient: Yes ,  We diagnosed my eye symptoms as possibly vaccine - related , and our patient subsequently opted not to continue with the second dose of my shot .  made me think carefully about it .
Doctor: I understand. Have you experienced any pain, redness, or sensitivity to light in your eyes recently?
Patient: Actually ,  There was no eye pain , redness , or photophobia in either eye .  although it was mild .
Doctor: Alright, have you noticed any symptoms of a viral-like illness, such as a cough, or fever, either before or after your vaccination?
Patient: Yes ,  No viral - like illness or symptoms , such as cough , upper respiratory tract illness , or fever , were reported before or after my shot .  which was a bit worrying .
Doctor: Let’s take a look at There is left eye yellowish raised elevation and hyperautofluorescence at the fovea with dome-shaped elevation of the RPE at the fovea causing disruption of the ellipsoid zone..
Patient: Oh, I wasn't aware of these specific details about my eye. What does this elevation at the fovea mean for my vision?
Doctor: Well,  Fundus photograph, ocular coherence tomography , fundus fluorescein angiography and indocyanine green angiography of the same patient at 15 days post vaccination showed improvement clinically. indicates some changes.
Patient: That's good to hear that there's improvement. Will the remaining lesion on the OCT eventually go away too?
Doctor: Likely, The refractive assessment showed bilateral low myope of −0.75D and mild astigmatism of −0.25D in the left eye, with a normal amplitude of accommodation 7.5D OU. but it might take some time.
Patient: That seems like a slight change in my vision. Does the low myopia or astigmatism affect me significantly?
Doctor: Generally, Left-eye metamorphopsia was noted on the Amsler chart, mostly around the central and paracentral regions. it shouldn’t be too concerning.
Patient: I noticed some distortion with my left eye; is that what metamorphopsia is?
Doctor: Exactly, The anterior segment examination via slit lamp biomicroscopy was unremarkable. describes just that.
Patient: It's good to know there's no inflammation. Does that mean my eyes are generally healthy?
Doctor: Yes, Fundus examination of the left eye showed a well-circumscribed, yellowish-raised elevation superior to the fovea. you are in good condition.
Patient: That sounds concerning. What does a raised elevation near the fovea indicate?
Doctor: It usually means ICGA showed hypocyanescence at the corresponding area on the fovea, with a hypocyanescent area noted at the inferonasal vessel arcade in the venous phase. which we'll monitor closely.
Patient: It sounds like there is some improvement, but what is a pigment epithelial defect, and should I be worried about it?
Doctor: No, Nope you shouldn't be too worried.
Patient: Will do. Thank you, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. Take care, and don’t hesitate to reach out if you have any more concerns.
Case 2:
Doctor: Hi! How are you feeling today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I’m feeling a bit better, but I still have some concerns.
Doctor: I see. Could you please share a little about yourself, and if you have any medical conditions or allergies?
Patient: Well , I 'm  ' A 68 - year - old Malay man . '
Doctor: Thanks for sharing that. Could you describe when you first experienced any issues with your vision after receiving the COVID-19 vaccination?
Patient: A 68 - year - old Malay man presented with sudden - onset right - eye central blur of vision 3 days after receiving my second dose of COVID-19 vaccination .
Doctor: Alright, before the second dose, did you have any medical conditions or previous eye issues that might have contributed to this?
Patient: I had no underlying medical illness and no significant past ocular history .
Doctor: I understand. After your first dose of the vaccine, did you notice any similar ocular symptoms or was this something new?
Patient: I did not have any eye symptoms after my first dose of the shot .
Doctor: Okay, have you experienced any symptoms following your recent vaccination?
Patient: $ No$
Doctor: Let's take a look at this image, Ocular coherence tomography showed loss of foveal contour with the presence of intraretinal and subretinal fluid, and a fibrovascular pigment epithelial defect (Figure 2A)..
Patient: Oh, I see. So, there’s no sign of macular degeneration or myopic changes, but there are some issues with fluid and a defect?
Doctor: Yes, exactly, OCT macula revealed resolution of intraretinal fluids; however, the subretinal fluid was similar in size and the fibrovascular PED was more defined (Figure 2B)..
Patient: Thanks for explaining that. It’s good to know the intraretinal fluid is resolved, but I’m concerned about the subretinal fluid and the more defined fibrovascular PED.
Doctor: That's a valid concern. Let's discuss further, your presenting visual acuity was 6/12 OD and 6/6 OS..
Patient: Okay, so my right eye isn't seeing as well as my left, and there's a lesion in the macula?
Doctor: Yes, that's correct, your presenting visual acuity was 6/12 OD and 6/6 OS..
Patient: Yes, I understand. What does the lesion mean for my vision in the future?
Doctor: Well, the situation is still being monitored, and currently, there are no specific answers, '$No$"'.
Patient: Will do. Thank you, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. Take care, and don’t hesitate to reach out if you have any more concerns.
Case 3:
Doctor: Hi! How are you feeling today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I’m feeling a bit better, but I still have some concerns.
Doctor: I see. Could you please share a little about yourself, and let me know if you have any medical conditions or allergies?
Patient: ' A 50 - year - old Malay woman with no underlying medical illness presented with double bl of vision 2 weeks after receiving me second dose of COVID-19 vaccination . '
Doctor: Alright, when did you first notice the symptoms related to your vision?
Patient: Me blurring of vision started 1 week after shot and did not improve over time .
Doctor: And how was your visual acuity at that time?
Patient: Me visual acuity was 6/18 OD and 6/12 OS .
Doctor: Did you notice any changes upon your next medical review?
Patient: Upon subsequent review , me macula edema and placoid lesions resolved 4 days later .
Doctor: I understand. What treatment were you given, and how did it affect your symptoms?
Patient: A week after being given in st , me symptoms resolved .
Doctor: So, how is your visual acuity and overall eye health now?
Patient: Me visual acuity was 6/6 OU , with no macula edema or placoid lesions seen both clinically and on eye pictures ( Figure 3B ) .
Doctor: Are you currently experiencing any symptoms or discomfort related to your health?
Patient: $ No$
Doctor: I see. Let's take a look at Fundus photo and OCT macula showing bilateral placoid lesions in the choroid with macula edema on presentation..
Patient: That sounds concerning. What does that mean for my vision?
Doctor: Fundus photo and OCT macula showing resolution of bilateral placoid lesions and macula edema one week post-treatment with intravenous methylprednisolone.
Patient: That's a relief to hear. So, the treatment is working well, right?
Doctor: The anterior segment examination was unremarkable, with no evidence of anterior segment inflammation.
Patient: That's good to hear. I was worried about possible inflammation.
Doctor: Posterior segment examination showed bilateral fibrinous placoid lesions in the choroid with severe inner and outer macula edema (Figure 3A).
Patient: That sounds concerning. What does that mean for my vision?
Doctor: Visual evoked potential and optic nerve conduction studies were normal.
Patient: So, thankfully, that means my optic nerve is functioning properly, right?
Doctor: The systemic examination was otherwise unremarkable.
Patient: I'm relieved to hear that nothing else seems to be out of the ordinary. What should be our next steps?
Doctor: 'A diagnosis of acute multifocal placoid pigment epitheliopathy was made based on clinical and investigational findings.'
Patient: Will do. Thank you, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. Take care, and don’t hesitate to reach out if you have any more concerns.
Case 4:
Doctor: Hi! How are you feeling today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I’m feeling a bit better, but I still have some concerns.
Doctor: I see. Could you please share a little about yourself and let me know if you have any medical conditions or allergies?
Patient: ' A 32 - year - old Malay woman who is a housewife with an underlying history of anxiety , panic disorder , and depression received me first dose of Oxford AstraZeneca ChAdOx1 COVID-19 vaccination . '
Doctor: That gives me a good overview. Can you tell me when you first started noticing symptoms related to your skin?
Patient: Two weeks after me shot , I developed multiple skin ir , vesicles , and crusty lesions over the right side of me face , respecting the center and involving the tip of the nose .
Doctor: And how did your symptoms progress after those initial skin issues?
Patient: A week later , following the onset of the skin , I developed sudden - onset red , itchiness , and mild blurring of vision in me right eye .
Doctor: I see. Did you experience any other symptoms or changes following the redness and vision issues with your right eye?
Patient: There was also right periorbital swelling , which resolved after 2 days .
Doctor: Have you experienced any symptoms such as fever, pain, or changes in your vision recently?
Patient: $ No$
Doctor: Let's take a look at $No$ now.
Patient: So, does that mean everything is looking normal?
Doctor: An ocular examination showed the presence of a circumciliary injection in you right eye.
Patient: I've noticed the redness around my right eye, so that makes sense.
Doctor: There was no evidence of cornea epithelial, stromal, or endothelial involvement.
Patient: That's reassuring to hear that my cornea isn't affected.
Doctor: The anterior chamber showed cell activity at 2+ with no keratic precipitates, hypopyons, or fibrinous reactions.
Patient: I'm glad my eye pressure is normal, but what does the cell activity mean?
Doctor: There was no evidence of posterior segment inflammation such as vitritis, retinitis, choroiditis, or vasculitis.
Patient: That's good to know there's no inflammation in the back part of my eye.
Doctor: Examination of the left eye was normal.
Patient: It's a relief that my left eye is just fine.
Doctor: 'you was treated for an underlying herpes zoster infection with right acute nongranulomatous anterior uveitis.', 'The diagnosis was made clinically.', 'you was treated with oral acyclovir at 800 mg five times a day, together with topical tobramycin at 0.3% and dexamethasone at 0.1% 4-hourly in you right eye.', 'Following treatment, the uveitis and skin lesions improved by two weeks and completely resolved at the 1-month follow-up.'
Patient: Will do. Thank you, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. Take care, and don’t hesitate to reach out if you have any more concerns.
